text:
(2)

A general view westward from the Brooklyn Bridge (under construction), over the Cherry Hill section, Printing House Square, City Hall Commons and westward to the Hudson (North) River. Shown in the foreground, is the Manhattan abutment of the bridge, with the Roosevelt Street Ferry to Broadway, Brooklyn adjoining. Points of interest shown are, U.S. Post Office, Tribune Building, Harper's and the Newsboy's Home.

About 1870-1875.

Brown Brothers.

Published in the American on December 1908, and the New York Times of October 20, 1912.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.

text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction, with the "Catwalk" and Manhattan anchorage in the foreground. Also shown is a general view westward over the City Hall and Printing House Square area, to the Hudson River, with its Jersey shore line just beyond. Note how the U.S. Post Office and the Tribune Buildings predominated at this date.

About 1878-1879.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.

text:
Central Park, the Mall: Bethesda Fountain, on the shore of the Lake (eastern bay), above the Esplanade at the northern end of the Mall. The design is by Miss Emma Stebbins, a New York sculptor; and represents the angel blessing the waters of the pool of Bethesda. In her left hand the angel holds a branch of lilies, emblem of purity. The four figures supporting the basin symbolize Temperance, Purity, Health, and Peace.

May, 1892.

Ewing Galloway.

315G
LOCAL HISTORY AND GENEALOGY
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Terrace Fountain and the Lake - The Mall.

original_title: Bronx: Pelham Parkway South - Sacket Avenue
text:
Morris Park Race Track (Bronx): Viewing north across the fashionable track from near the grand stand. The track was bounded on the east by Williamsbridge Road; on the west by Barnes Avenue; on the north by Pelham Parkway; and on the south by Sackett Avenue. In June, 1913 "the most remarkable real estate sale in the history of the city", as the New York Times commented editorially, took place when the track property was offered for auction by Joseph P. Day and Clarence Davies. For additional data see "The New York Times," April 27, June 15, and June 22, 1913.

About 1910?
Views 1,2:
Probably earlier.

Fifth Avenue, west side, north, from a point to the south of W. 42nd Street and across same.

About 1910

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Poppy Joe Island Beach (Staten Island): A group of local muskrat hunters and hunting dogs in front of their work-and-storage barn. From left to right they are: Louis Stroud, George W. Stroud, John ("Jeff") Davis, and James A. Stroud. Poppy Joe Island is on the Lower New York Bay, near New Creek, between Ocean Breeze and Midland Beach.

About 1911

Photo by J.E. Davis
Copied by P. L. Sperr
title: Staten Island - Poppy Joe Island Beach - [Stroud place.]

text:
North on Fifth Avenue from S. W. corner of 42nd Street, showing early type of Fifth Avenue motor-drawn bus,. Bristol Building, formerly Bristol Hotel, at left foreground. Temple Emanu-El at right centre.
1912.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

East 42nd Street, north side, east from Fifth Ave., showing construction work in progress on Grand Central Station, Vanderbilt Ave., to Depew Place (no longer in existence). Grand Central station was opened in 1913 and is the terminal for the new York Central Railroad, and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad
Prior to 1913.

Ewing Galloway.

TEN THOUSAND NEW YORK SCHOOLBOYS DRILLING IN CENTRAL PARK.
This is a great army of schoolboys from all boroughs of the big city, attired in white shirtwaists & dark knickerbockers, gave an exhibition drill in the physical exercises in the city's largest park last month before a distinguished company of invited guests, relatives & friends.  The purpose of this impressive demonstration, which was held under the auspices of the Public Schools Athletic League, was to show the results of physical and hygienic training in the schools.  Colonel Roosevelt, who was one of the spectators, spoke of the work of the League as a great force for good not only in the city but in the nation.

Dated:  June 10, 1913.  American Press Ass'n
title: Manhattan: Central Park.

150th Street, west side, north of One Hundred Forty-seventh Ave. This set consists of four views showing the Christian Nicklaus farmhouse. For further data, see additional views. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

110-14 - 110-16 Colonial Avenue, east side, south from Nassau Boulevard (to be constructed at right of house in foreground). Van Doren Street is seen in the foreground. This set of three views shows the De La Carte living quarters and Inn. of 1922. It was erected by John Heeg who kept a roadhouse. Arthur Mayer owned it in 1897. He was followed by William Gier.

Jan. 1924.
Views 2&3: May 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

Minetta Lane, from MacDougal Street, to the intersection of Sixth Ave. and Carmine Street, showing a modern paved street with several new buildings.
About 1925.

Prospect Park,Plaza: A general view east from the Knights of Columbus Building located at the N.W. corner of President Street and Prospect Park West, showing in the foreground the Memorial Arch.  In the center of the view, east from Flatbush Ave., (trolley car thereon) is Eastern Parkway.  The buildings on the south side of the Parkway are the Mt. Prospect Reservoir, and the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences; on the north side in their order are the Union Temple of Brooklyn, the Copley Plaza Apartments (under construction), the Abraham Lincoln, etc.

June 1926.

Brown Brothers.

text:
West 42nd Street, east from Sixth Ave. Overhead is the "L" structure that acquires its name from this Avenue.
April 3, 1933.
Irvin., Fitterman.

Central Park: Aerial View from Radio City (Sixth Avenue and 51st Street), showing the Park and the Fifth Avenue side. In the center foreground may be seen the Pond, north of it the Mall, then the Lake, of which the eastern bay is at the northern end of the Mall and the main body on the west side of the Park, about 70th to 80th Streets. The bare spot further north is the site of the old reservoir; above it may be seen the north reservoir, still in use. The buildings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art may be seen on the Fifth Avenue side at 81st Street.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, another view. In the southwestern quarter of the Park may be seen a ball ground, and north of it the Meadow or Green. The 72nd Street cross drive separates the Green and the Lake.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, also showing the West Side of town and the Hudson River. The Riverside Church, at 122nd Street, and the George Washington Bridge, at 181st Street, stand out very clearly.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Aerial view from Radio City.

text:
Central Park: The Mall, crowd with roller skaters. During this and the following year, this sport, always more or less popular, suddenly became a craze; young, middle aged, and old, children and adults, all took to roller skates. The Mall and the Central Park walks, together with the east sidewalk of Central Park West, were favorite locations, but by no means the only ones.
May 15, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, another view.
May 15, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same another view.
The seated statue represents Fitz-Greene Halleck, by Wilson MacDonald (erected in 1877).
May 15, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Mall.

text:
Celebrations: Pay Tribute to Columbus. About 1,000 gathered around Columbus Circle October 12, to pay tribute to the Great Navigator on the 441st Anniversary of his discovery of America. Wreaths were placed at the base of the statue, and addressed in tribute to Columbus were made. Mayor O'Brien was one of those to speak. Here is a general view looking into Central Park in Background.

Associated Press Photo

October 12, 1933.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Celebrations - Tribute to Columbus.
